standard_metadata.standard_description: Solve real-world and mathematical problems by writing and solving equations of the form x + p = q and px = q for cases in which p, q and x are all nonnegative rational numbers.
standard_metadata.standard_title: Find the mistake in one-step equations

question.content: Carly tried to solve an equation.  $\begin{align} 7a&=28\\\\ \dfrac{7a}a&=\dfrac{28}7&\tealE{\text{Setting up}}\\\\ 7&=4&\purpleD{\text{Calculating}} \end{align}$  **Where did Carly make their first mistake?**

hints.content: ###Strategy  To $\tealE{\text{set up}}$ the equation for solving, Carly needs to perform the same operation on both sides of the equation.  To $\purpleD{\text{calculate}}$ the solution, Carly needs to correctly solve the equation they $\tealE{\text{set up}}$.  If Carly both $\tealE{\text{set up}}$ and $\purpleD{\text{calculated}}$ the solution correctly, then they correctly solved the equation.

When $\tealE{\text{setting up}}$ the equation for solving, Carly divided the left side of the equation by $a$ and the right side of the equation by $7$.  This is a mistake!  Carly should have divided both sides of the equation by $7$.
###Answer  Carly's first mistake was in $\tealE{\text{setting up}}$.

question.content: Alanna tried to solve an equation.  $\begin{align} 4c&=12\\\\ \dfrac{4c}{4}&=12\cdot4&\tealE{\text{Setting up}}\\\\ c&=48&\purpleD{\text{Calculating}} \end{align}$  **Where did Alanna make her first mistake?**

hints.content: ###Strategy  To $\tealE{\text{set up}}$ the equation for solving, Alanna needs to perform the same operation on both sides of the equation.  To $\purpleD{\text{calculate}}$ the solution, Alanna needs to correctly solve the equation she $\tealE{\text{set up}}$.  If Alanna both $\tealE{\text{set up}}$ and $\purpleD{\text{calculated}}$ the solution correctly, then she correctly solved the equation.

When $\tealE{\text{setting up}}$ the equation for solving, Alanna divided the left side of the equation by $4$ and multiplied the right side of the equation by $4$.  This is a mistake!  Alanna should have divided both sides of the equation by $4$.
###Answer  Alanna's first mistake was in $\tealE{\text{setting up}}$.

question.content: Trent tried to solve an equation.  $\begin{align} \dfrac g{3}&=\dfrac43\\\\ \dfrac{g}{3} \cdot 3&=\dfrac43\cdot\dfrac13&\tealE{\text{Setting up}}\\\\ g&=\dfrac49&\purpleD{\text{Calculating}} \end{align}$  **Where did Trent make his first mistake?**

hints.content: ###Strategy  To $\tealE{\text{set up}}$ the equation for solving, Trent needs to perform the same operation on both sides of the equation.  To $\purpleD{\text{calculate}}$ the solution, Trent needs to correctly solve the equation he $\tealE{\text{set up}}$.  If Trent both $\tealE{\text{set up}}$ and $\purpleD{\text{calculated}}$ the solution correctly, then he correctly solved the equation.

When $\tealE{\text{setting up}}$ the equation for solving, Trent multiplied the left side of the equation by $3$ and the right side of the equation by $\dfrac{1}{3}$.  This is a mistake!  Trent should have multiplied both sides of the equation by $3$.
###Answer  Trent's first mistake was in $\tealE{\text{setting up}}$.

question.content: Subira tried to solve an equation.  $\begin{align} \dfrac h{0.5}&=7\\\\ \dfrac{h}{0.5} \cdot 0.5&=\dfrac7{0.5}&\tealE{\text{Setting up}}\\\\ h&=14&\purpleD{\text{Calculating}} \end{align}$  **Where did Subira make her first mistake?**

hints.content: ###Strategy  To $\tealE{\text{set up}}$ the equation for solving, Subira needs to perform the same operation on both sides of the equation.  To $\purpleD{\text{calculate}}$ the solution, Subira needs to correctly solve the equation she $\tealE{\text{set up}}$.  If Subira both $\tealE{\text{set up}}$ and $\purpleD{\text{calculated}}$ the solution correctly, then she correctly solved the equation.

When $\tealE{\text{setting up}}$ the equation for solving, Subira multiplied the left side of the equation by $0.5$ and divided the right side of the equation by $0.5$.  This is a mistake!  Subira should have multiplied both sides of the equation by $0.5$.
###Answer  Subira's first mistake was in $\tealE{\text{setting up}}$.

question.content: Oscar tried to solve an equation.  $\begin{align} \dfrac34+m&=\dfrac54\\\\ \dfrac34+m-\dfrac34&=\dfrac54+\dfrac34&\tealE{\text{Setting up}}\\\\ m&=2&\purpleD{\text{Calculating}} \end{align}$  **Where did Oscar make his first mistake?**

hints.content: ###Strategy  To $\tealE{\text{set up}}$ the equation for solving, Oscar needs to perform the same operation on both sides of the equation.  To $\purpleD{\text{calculate}}$ the solution, Oscar needs to correctly solve the equation he $\tealE{\text{set up}}$.  If Oscar both $\tealE{\text{set up}}$ and $\purpleD{\text{calculated}}$ the solution correctly, then he correctly solved the equation.

When $\tealE{\text{setting up}}$ the equation for solving, Oscar subtracted $\dfrac{3}{4}$ from the left side of the equation and added $\dfrac{3}{4}$ to the right side of the equation.  This is a mistake!  Oscar should have subtracted $\dfrac{3}{4}$ from both sides of the equation.
###Answer  Oscar's first mistake was in $\tealE{\text{setting up}}$.

question.content: Ling tried to solve an equation.  $\begin{align} 12&=p+6.2\\\\ 12+6.2&=p+6.2-6.2&\tealE{\text{Setting up}}\\\\ 18.2&=p&\purpleD{\text{Calculating}} \end{align}$  **Where did Ling make their first mistake?**

hints.content: ###Strategy  To $\tealE{\text{set up}}$ the equation for solving, Ling needs to perform the same operation on both sides of the equation.  To $\purpleD{\text{calculate}}$ the solution, Ling needs to correctly solve the equation they $\tealE{\text{set up}}$.  If Ling both $\tealE{\text{set up}}$ and $\purpleD{\text{calculated}}$ the solution correctly, then they correctly solved the equation.

When $\tealE{\text{setting up}}$ the equation for solving, Ling added $6.2$ to the left side of the equation and subtracted $6.2$ from the right side of the equation.  This is a mistake!  Ling should have subtracted $6.2$ from both sides of the equation.
###Answer  Ling's first mistake was in $\tealE{\text{setting up}}$.

question.content: Katy tried to solve an equation.  $\begin{align} r-3&=14.3\\\\ r-3+3&=14.3-3&\tealE{\text{Setting up}}\\\\ r&=11.3&\purpleD{\text{Calculating}} \end{align}$  **Where did Katy make her first mistake?**

hints.content: ###Strategy  To $\tealE{\text{set up}}$ the equation for solving, Katy needs to perform the same operation on both sides of the equation.  To $\purpleD{\text{calculate}}$ the solution, Katy needs to correctly solve the equation she $\tealE{\text{set up}}$.  If Katy both $\tealE{\text{set up}}$ and $\purpleD{\text{calculated}}$ the solution correctly, then she correctly solved the equation.

When $\tealE{\text{setting up}}$ the equation for solving, Katy added $3$ to the left side of the equation and subtracted $3$ from the right side of the equation.  This is a mistake!  Katy should have added $3$ to both sides of the equation.
###Answer  Katy's first mistake was in $\tealE{\text{setting up}}$.

question.content: Nasir tried to solve an equation.  $\begin{align} 7.7&=w-2\\\\ 7.7-2&=w-2+2&\tealE{\text{Setting up}}\\\\ 5.7&=w&\purpleD{\text{Calculating}} \end{align}$  **Where did Nasir make his first mistake?**

hints.content: ###Strategy  To $\tealE{\text{set up}}$ the equation for solving, Nasir needs to perform the same operation on both sides of the equation.  To $\purpleD{\text{calculate}}$ the solution, Nasir needs to correctly solve the equation he $\tealE{\text{set up}}$.  If Nasir both $\tealE{\text{set up}}$ and $\purpleD{\text{calculated}}$ the solution correctly, then he correctly solved the equation.

When $\tealE{\text{setting up}}$ the equation for solving, Nasir subtracted $2$ from the left side of the equation and added $2$ to the right side of the equation.  This is a mistake!  Nasir should have added $2$ to both sides of the equation.
###Answer  Nasir's first mistake was in $\tealE{\text{setting up}}$.

question.content: Marcus tried to solve an equation.  $\begin{align} 2.5b&=5\\\\ \dfrac{2.5b}{2.5}&=\dfrac{5}{2.5}&\tealE{\text{Setting up}}\\\\ b&=3&\purpleD{\text{Calculating}} \end{align}$  **Where did Marcus make his first mistake?**

hints.content: ###Strategy  To $\tealE{\text{set up}}$ the equation for solving, Marcus needs to perform the same operation on both sides of the equation.  To $\purpleD{\text{calculate}}$ the solution, Marcus needs to correctly solve the equation he $\tealE{\text{set up}}$.  If Marcus both $\tealE{\text{set up}}$ and $\purpleD{\text{calculated}}$ the solution correctly, then he correctly solved the equation.
Marcus divided both sides of the equation by $2.5$ to get $b$ by itself.  He correctly $\tealE{\text{set up}}$ the equation.
Marcus then evaluated $\dfrac{5}{2.5}$ to get $3$.  This is a mistake!  $\dfrac5{2.5}$ equals $2$, not $3$.  He did not correctly $\purpleD{\text{calculate}}$ the solution.
###Answer  Marcus's first mistake was in $\purpleD{\text{calculating}}$.

question.content: Derek tried to solve an equation.  $\begin{align} 8d&=72\\\\ \dfrac{8d}{8}&=\dfrac{72}8&\tealE{\text{Setting up}}\\\\ d&=8&\purpleD{\text{Calculating}} \end{align}$  **Where did Derek make his first mistake?**

hints.content: ###Strategy  To $\tealE{\text{set up}}$ the equation for solving, Derek needs to perform the same operation on both sides of the equation.  To $\purpleD{\text{calculate}}$ the solution, Derek needs to correctly solve the equation he $\tealE{\text{set up}}$.  If Derek both $\tealE{\text{set up}}$ and $\purpleD{\text{calculated}}$ the solution correctly, then he correctly solved the equation.
Derek divided both sides of the equation by $8$ to get $d$ by itself.  He correctly $\tealE{\text{set up}}$ the equation.
Derek then evaluated $\dfrac{72}{8}$ to get $8$.  This is a mistake!  $\dfrac{72}{8}$ equals $9$, not $8$ .  He did not correctly $\purpleD{\text{calculate}}$ the solution.
###Answer  Derek's first mistake was in $\purpleD{\text{calculating}}$.

question.content: Gary tried to solve an equation.  $\begin{align} \dfrac e{4}&=2.5\\\\ \dfrac{e}4 \cdot4&=2.5\cdot4&\tealE{\text{Setting up}}\\\\ e&=8&\purpleD{\text{Calculating}} \end{align}$  **Where did Gary make his first mistake?**

hints.content: ###Strategy  To $\tealE{\text{set up}}$ the equation for solving, Gary needs to perform the same operation on both sides of the equation.  To $\purpleD{\text{calculate}}$ the solution, Gary needs to correctly solve the equation he $\tealE{\text{set up}}$.  If Gary both $\tealE{\text{set up}}$ and $\purpleD{\text{calculated}}$ the solution correctly, then he correctly solved the equation.
Gary multiplied both sides of the equation by $4$ to get $e$ by itself.  He correctly $\tealE{\text{set up}}$ the equation.
Gary then evaluated $2.5\cdot4$ to get $8$.  This is a mistake!  $2.5\cdot 4 = 10$, not $8$.  He did not correctly $\purpleD{\text{calculate}}$ the solution.
###Answer  Gary's first mistake was in $\purpleD{\text{calculating}}$.

question.content: Rita tried to solve an equation.  $\begin{align} n+12&=18.3\\\\ n+12-12&=18.3-12&\tealE{\text{Setting up}}\\\\ n&=5.7&\purpleD{\text{Calculating}} \end{align}$  **Where did Rita make her first mistake?**

hints.content: ###Strategy  To $\tealE{\text{set up}}$ the equation for solving, Rita needs to perform the same operation on both sides of the equation.  To $\purpleD{\text{calculate}}$ the solution, Rita needs to correctly solve the equation she $\tealE{\text{set up}}$.  If Rita both $\tealE{\text{set up}}$ and $\purpleD{\text{calculated}}$ the solution correctly, then she correctly solved the equation.
Rita subtracted $12$ from both sides of the equation to get $n$ by itself.  She correctly $\tealE{\text{set up}}$ the equation.
Rita then evaluated $18.3-12$ to get $5.7$.  This is a mistake!  $18.3-12$ equals $6.3$, not $5.7$.  She did not correctly $\purpleD{\text{calculate}}$ the solution.
###Answer  Rita's first mistake was in $\purpleD{\text{calculating}}$.

question.content: Quinn tried to solve an equation.  $\begin{align} \dfrac43&=q+\dfrac13\\\\ \dfrac43-\dfrac13&=q+\dfrac13-\dfrac13&\tealE{\text{Setting up}}\\\\ \dfrac23&=q&\purpleD{\text{Calculating}} \end{align}$  **Where did Quinn make their first mistake?**

hints.content: ###Strategy  To $\tealE{\text{set up}}$ the equation for solving, Quinn needs to perform the same operation on both sides of the equation.  To $\purpleD{\text{calculate}}$ the solution, Quinn needs to correctly solve the equation they $\tealE{\text{set up}}$.  If Quinn both $\tealE{\text{set up}}$ and $\purpleD{\text{calculated}}$ the solution correctly, then they correctly solved the equation.
Quinn subtracted $\dfrac{1}{3}$ from both sides of the equation to get $q$ by itself.  They correctly $\tealE{\text{set up}}$ the equation.

Quinn then evaluated $\dfrac43-\dfrac13$ to get  $\dfrac23$.  This is a mistake!  $\dfrac43-\dfrac13$ equals $\dfrac33$ or $1$, not $\dfrac23$.  They did not correctly $\purpleD{\text{calculate}}$ the solution.
###Answer  Quinn's first mistake was in $\purpleD{\text{calculating}}$.

question.content: Emma tried to solve an equation.  $\begin{align} t-\dfrac35&=\dfrac45\\\\ t-\dfrac35+\dfrac35&=\dfrac45+\dfrac35&\tealE{\text{Setting up}}\\\\ t&=1&\purpleD{\text{Calculating}} \end{align}$  **Where did Emma make her first mistake?**

hints.content: ###Strategy  To $\tealE{\text{set up}}$ the equation for solving, Emma needs to perform the same operation on both sides of the equation.  To $\purpleD{\text{calculate}}$ the solution, Emma needs to correctly solve the equation she $\tealE{\text{set up}}$.  If Emma both $\tealE{\text{set up}}$ and $\purpleD{\text{calculated}}$ the solution correctly, then she correctly solved the equation.
Emma added $\dfrac{3}{5}$ to both sides of the equation to get $t$ by itself.  She correctly $\tealE{\text{set up}}$ the equation.
Emma then evaluated $\dfrac45+\dfrac35$ to get  $1$.  This is a mistake!  $\dfrac45+\dfrac35$ equals $\dfrac75$, not $1$.  She did not correctly $\purpleD{\text{calculate}}$ the solution.
###Answer  Emma's first mistake was in $\purpleD{\text{calculating}}$.

question.content: Ofra tried to solve an equation.  $\begin{align} 3x&=4.5\\\\ \dfrac{3x}3&=\dfrac{4.5}3&\tealE{\text{Setting up}}\\\\ x&=1.5&\purpleD{\text{Calculating}} \end{align}$  **Where did Ofra make her first mistake?**

hints.content: ###Strategy  To $\tealE{\text{set up}}$ the equation for solving, Ofra needs to perform the same operation on both sides of the equation.  To $\purpleD{\text{calculate}}$ the solution, Ofra needs to correctly solve the equation she $\tealE{\text{set up}}$.  If Ofra both $\tealE{\text{set up}}$ and $\purpleD{\text{calculated}}$ the solution correctly, then she correctly solved the equation.
Ofra divided both sides of the equation by $3$ to get $x$ by itself.  She correctly $\tealE{\text{set up}}$ the equation.
Ofra then evaluated $\dfrac{4.5}{3}$ to get  $1.5$.  She correctly $\purpleD{\text{calculated}}$ the solution.
###Answer  Ofra correctly solved the equation.

question.content: Paulo tried to solve an equation.  $\begin{align} \dfrac f{0.25}&=16\\\\ \dfrac{f}{0.25} \cdot0.25&=16\cdot0.25&\tealE{\text{Setting up}}\\\\ f&=4&\purpleD{\text{Calculating}} \end{align}$  **Where did Paulo make his first mistake?**

hints.content: ###Strategy  To $\tealE{\text{set up}}$ the equation for solving, Paulo needs to perform the same operation on both sides of the equation.  To $\purpleD{\text{calculate}}$ the solution, Paulo needs to correctly solve the equation he $\tealE{\text{set up}}$.  If Paulo both $\tealE{\text{set up}}$ and $\purpleD{\text{calculated}}$ the solution correctly, then he correctly solved the equation.
Paulo multiplied both sides of the equation by $0.25$ to get $f$ by itself.  He correctly $\tealE{\text{set up}}$ the equation.
Paulo then evaluated $16\cdot0.25$ to get  $4$.  He correctly $\purpleD{\text{calculated}}$ the solution.
###Answer  Paulo correctly solved the equation.

question.content: Gabi tried to solve an equation.  $\begin{align} \dfrac j{10}&=80\\\\ \dfrac{j}{10} \cdot 10&=80 \cdot10&\tealE{\text{Setting up}}\\\\ j&=800&\purpleD{\text{Calculating}} \end{align}$  **Where did Gabi make her first mistake?**

hints.content: ###Strategy  To $\tealE{\text{set up}}$ the equation for solving, Gabi needs to perform the same operation on both sides of the equation.  To $\purpleD{\text{calculate}}$ the solution, Gabi needs to correctly solve the equation she $\tealE{\text{set up}}$.  If Gabi both $\tealE{\text{set up}}$ and $\purpleD{\text{calculated}}$ the solution correctly, then she correctly solved the equation.
Gabi multiplied both sides of the equation by $10$ to get $j$ by itself.  She correctly $\tealE{\text{set up}}$ the equation.
Gabi then evaluated $80\cdot 10$ to get  $800$.  She correctly $\purpleD{\text{calculated}}$ the solution.
###Answer  Gabi correctly solved the equation.

question.content: Jackie tried to solve an equation.  $\begin{align} 7.5+k&=10\\\\ 7.5+k-7.5&=10-7.5&\tealE{\text{Setting up}}\\\\ k&=2.5&\purpleD{\text{Calculating}} \end{align}$  **Where did Jackie make their first mistake?**

hints.content: ###Strategy  To $\tealE{\text{set up}}$ the equation for solving, Jackie needs to perform the same operation on both sides of the equation.  To $\purpleD{\text{calculate}}$ the solution, Jackie needs to correctly solve the equation they $\tealE{\text{set up}}$.  If Jackie both $\tealE{\text{set up}}$ and $\purpleD{\text{calculated}}$ the solution correctly, then they correctly solved the equation.
Jackie subtracted $7.5$ from both sides of the equation  to get $k$ by itself.  They correctly $\tealE{\text{set up}}$ the equation.
Jackie then evaluated $10-7.5$ to get  $2.5$.  They correctly $\purpleD{\text{calculated}}$ the solution.
###Answer  Jackie correctly solved the equation.

question.content: Veronica tried to solve an equation.  $\begin{align} 8&=y-4.6\\\\ 8+4.6&=y-4.6+4.6&\tealE{\text{Setting up}}\\\\ 12.6&=y&\purpleD{\text{Calculating}} \end{align}$  **Where did Veronica make her first mistake?**

hints.content: ###Strategy  To $\tealE{\text{set up}}$ the equation for solving, Veronica needs to perform the same operation on both sides of the equation.  To $\purpleD{\text{calculate}}$ the solution, Veronica needs to correctly solve the equation she $\tealE{\text{set up}}$.  If Veronica both $\tealE{\text{set up}}$ and $\purpleD{\text{calculated}}$ the solution correctly, then she correctly solved the equation.
Veronica added $4.6$  to both sides of the equation to get $y$ by itself.  She correctly $\tealE{\text{set up}}$ the equation.
Veronica then evaluated $8+4.6$ to get  $12.6$.  She correctly $\purpleD{\text{calculated}}$ the solution.
###Answer  Veronica correctly solved the equation.

question.content: Zach tried to solve an equation.  $\begin{align} \dfrac34&=z-\dfrac12\\\\ \dfrac34+\dfrac12&=z-\dfrac12+\dfrac12&\tealE{\text{Setting up}}\\\\ \dfrac54&=z&\purpleD{\text{Calculating}} \end{align}$  **Where did Zach make his first mistake?**

hints.content: ###Strategy  To $\tealE{\text{set up}}$ the equation for solving, Zach needs to perform the same operation on both sides of the equation.  To $\purpleD{\text{calculate}}$ the solution, Zach needs to correctly solve the equation he $\tealE{\text{set up}}$.  If Zach both $\tealE{\text{set up}}$ and $\purpleD{\text{calculated}}$ the solution correctly, then he correctly solved the equation.
Zach added $\dfrac{1}{2}$ to both sides of the equation to get $z$ by itself.  He correctly $\tealE{\text{set up}}$ the equation.
Zach then evaluated $\dfrac34+\dfrac12$ to get  $\dfrac54$.  He correctly $\purpleD{\text{calculated}}$ the solution.  [[☃ explanation 1]]
###Answer  Zach correctly solved the equation.
